column1: #Text=Additional Configuration for Appliances on VMware vSphere
#Text=Installing ManageIQ consists of the following steps:
#Text=Downloading the appliance for your environment as a virtual machine
#Text=Setting up a virtual machine based on the appliance.
#Text=After you have completed all the procedures in this guide, you will have
#Text=a working environment on which additional customizations and
#Text=Uploading the ManageIQ appliance file onto VMware vSphere systems
#Text=44 GB of space on the chosen vSphere datastore.
#Text=Depending on your infrastructure, allow time for the upload.
#Text=These are the procedural steps as of the time of writing.
#Text=Use the following procedure to upload the ManageIQ appliance OVF template from your local file system using the vSphere Client.
#Text=In the vSphere Client, select menu:File[Deploy OVF Template].
#Text=Specify the source location and click Next.
#Text=Select Deploy from File to browse your file system for the
#Text=Select Deploy from URL to specify a URL to an OVF template
#Text=View the OVF Template Details page and click Next.
#Text=Select the deployment configuration from the drop-down menu and
#Text=The option selected typically controls the memory
#Text=settings, number of CPUs and reservations, and application-level
#Text=Select the host or cluster on which you want to deploy the OVF
#Text=Select the host on which you want to run the run the ManageIQ
#Text=Navigate to, and select the resource pool where you want to run the
#Text=Select a datastore to store the deployed ManageIQ appliance,
#Text=Ensure to select a datastore large enough to
#Text=accommodate the virtual machine and all of its virtual disk files.
#Text=Select the disk format to store the virtual machine virtual disks,
#Text=Select Thin Provisioned if the storage is allocated on
#Text=demand as data is written to the virtual disks.
#Text=Select Thick Provisioned if all storage is immediately
#Text=For each network specified in the OVF template, select a network by
#Text=right-clicking the Destination Network column in your
#Text=infrastructure to set up the network mapping and click Next.
#Text=The IP Allocation page does not require any configuration
#Text=Leave the default settings in the IP Allocation page
#Text=Set the user-configurable properties and click Next.
#Text=properties to enter depend on the selected IP allocation scheme.
#Text=example, you are prompted for IP related information for the
#Text=deployed virtual machines only in the case of a fixed IP allocation
#Text=The progress of the import task appears in the vSphere Client Status
#Text=After installing ManageIQ and running it for the first
#Text=time, you must perform some basic configuration.
#Text=Add a disk to the infrastructure hosting your appliance.
#Text=Configure the ManageIQ appliance using the internal
#Text=Start the appliance and open a terminal console.
#Text=Press the number for the item you want to change, and press Enter.
#Text=The options for your selection are displayed.
#Text=Follow the prompts to make the changes.
#Text=Press Enter to accept a setting where applicable.
#Text=The ManageIQ appliance console automatically logs out
#Text=ManageIQ uses a database to store information about the
#Text=options for it; ManageIQ provides the following two
#Text=Install an internal PostgreSQL database to the appliance
#Text=Configure the appliance to use an external PostgreSQL database
#Text=Before installing an internal database, add a disk to the infrastructure
#Text=infrastructure for instructions for adding a disk.
#Text=usually cannot be added while a virtual machine is running, Red Hat
#Text=recommends adding the disk before starting the appliance.
#Text=ManageIQ only supports installing of an internal VMDB on blank
#Text=disks; installation will fail if the disks are not blank.
#Text=Start the appliance and open a terminal console.
#Text=You are prompted to create or fetch an encryption key.
#Text=If this is the first ManageIQ appliance, choose Create
#Text=If this is not the first ManageIQ appliance, choose
#Text=Fetch key from remote machine to fetch the key from the
#Text=For worker and multi-region setups, use this
#Text=option to copy key from another appliance.
#Text=Choose Create Internal Database for the database location.
#Text=This can be either a disk you
#Text=attached previously, or a partition on the current disk.
#Text=Red Hat recommends using a separate disk for the database.
#Text=If there is an unpartitioned disk attached to the virtual machine,
#Text=the dialog will show options similar to the following:
#Text=Enter 1 to choose /dev/vdb for the database location.
#Text=option creates a logical volume using this device and mounts the
#Text=volume to the appliance in a location appropriate for storing

#Text=Enter 2 to continue without partitioning the disk.

#Text=multiple zones, such as database zone, user interface zone, and

#Text=appliances in these zones must be configured to use an external
#Text=The postgresql.conf file used with ManageIQ databases requires

#Text=Additional Configuration for Appliances on VMware vSphere
#Text=Execution of SmartState Analysis on virtual machines within a VMware
#Text=environment requires the Virtual Disk Development Kit (VDDK).
#Text=version of ManageIQ supports VDDK versions 6.0, 6.5, and
#Text=If you do not already have a login ID to VMware, then you will
#Text=At the time of this writing, the file can be
#Text=version from the drop-down list, then click the Drivers &
#Text=Expand Automation Tools and SDKs, and click
#Text=Go to Downloads next to the VMware vSphere Virtual Disk
#Text=searching for it using the Search on the VMware site.
#Text=See VMware documentation for information about their policy
#Text=concerning backward and forward compatibility for VDDK.
#Text=file to the /root directory of the appliance.
#Text=Start an SSH session into the appliance.
#Text=Run ldconfig to instruct ManageIQ to find the newly
#Text=Use the following command to verify the VDDK files are listed and
#Text=The VDDK is now installed on the ManageIQ appliance.
#Text=enables use of the SmartState Analysis server role on the appliance.
#Text=By default, the ManageIQ appliance uses the tuned
#Text=service and its virtual-guest profile to optimize performance.
#Text=cases, this profile provides the best performance for the appliance.
#Text=However on some VMware setups (for example, with a large vCenter
#Text=database), the following additional tuning may further improve appliance
#Text=When using the virtual-guest profile in tuned, edit the
#Text=vm.swappiness setting to 1 in the tuned.conf file from the
#Text=details on the best scheduler for your environment.
#Text=in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Performance Tuning Guide for
#Text=instructions on changing the default I/O scheduler.
#Text=Once ManageIQ is installed, you can log in and perform
#Text=Log in to ManageIQ for the first time after installing by:
#Text=Navigate to the URL for the login screen.
#Text=Change your password to ensure more private and secure access to
#Text=Navigate to the URL for the login screen.
#Text=Click Update Password beneath the Username and Password
#Text=Enter your current Username and Password in the text fields.
#Text=Input a new password in the New Password field.
#Text=Repeat your new password in the Verify Password field.

#Text=Currently, the appliance_console_cli feature is a subset of the full functionality of the appliance_console itself, and covers functions most likely to be scripted by using the command-line interface (CLI).
#Text=After starting the ManageIQ appliance, log in with a user name of root and the default password of smartvm.
#Text=This displays the Bash prompt for the root user.

#Text=Enter the appliance_console_cli or appliance_console_cli --help command to see a list of options available with the command, or simply enter appliance_console_cli --option <argument> directly to use a specific option.
#Text=region number (create a new region in the database - requires database credentials passed)
#Text=internal database (create a database on the current appliance)
#Text=database disk device path (for configuring an internal database)
#Text=fetch the v2_key from the given host
#Text=create or fetch the key even if one exists
#Text=ssh username for fetching the v2_key (defaults to root)
#Text=set the appliance hostname to the given name
#Text=Will be based on the appliance domain name if not specified.
#Text=Will be based on the domain name of the ipaserver if not specified.

#Text=In order to configure authentication through an IPA server, in addition to using Configure External Authentication (httpd) in the appliance_console, external authentication can be optionally configured via the appliance_console_cli (command-line interface).
#Text=Specifying –host will update the hostname of the appliance.
#Text=If this step was already performed via the appliance_console and the necessary updates that are made to /etc/hosts if DNS is not properly configured, the –host option can be omitted.
#Text=install certs for http server (to create certs/httpd* values for a unique key)

#Text=Note: The certificate options augment the functionality of the certmonger tool and enable creating a certificate signing request (CSR), and specifying certmonger the directories to store the keys.
#Text=initialize the given device for temp storage (volume mounted at /var/www/miq_tmp)

#Text=You could combine the two to join a region where db.example.com is the appliance hosting the database:
#Text=# appliance_console_cli --fetch-key db.example.com --sshlogin root --sshpassword smartvm --hostname db.example.com --password mydatabasepassword
